question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
Taking the derivative of this function yields

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = 1 -\frac{1}{x^{2}}\)

The derivative is undefined at x = 0 (as is the original function) and setting the derivative to 0 also gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{x^{2}} &= 1 \\ x &= \pm 1 \end{aligned}\]

Thus \(\displaystyle f\) has three critical points and four intervals to check:

  • On \(\displaystyle (-\infty, -1)\) the derivative is positive and the function is increasing.

  • On \(\displaystyle (-1,0)\) the derivative is negative and the function is decreasing.

  • On \(\displaystyle (0,1)\) the derivative is negative and the function is decreasing.

  • On \(\displaystyle (1,\infty)\) the derivative is positive and the function is increasing.

Therefore the function is increasing on \({\color{blue} \displaystyle (-\infty,-1) \cup(1,\infty)}\).
